samples.prompt: I just feel so lost right now. It's been weeks since the breakup, but I can't stop thinking about them. Part of me knows it was toxic—they said such cruel things, and I was always walking on eggshells. But another part keeps replaying the good moments, wondering if I overreacted. I cry at random times, and I hate how weak that makes me feel.
samples.gold_answer: Your heart is holding so much right now—the whiplash between those sharp memories and the tender ones can feel unbearable. It makes sense to grieve both what was *and* what never could be. Crying isn’t weakness; it’s your body honoring how deeply you cared. Would it help to gently untangle those conflicting feelings together? To explore what your mind clings to in the "good moments," and what your gut knew when you walked away? You’re not overreacting—you’re relearning how to trust yourself.
gold_reasoning: Okay, the client is feeling lost after a breakup that happened weeks ago.

I should avoid any clinical terms.
